PERIODIC TABLE

The modern periodic law is based on atomic number while Mendeleev law is based on relative atomic masses. The modern periodic law states that the properties of the elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers. Rutherford classified elements before Mendeleev.

Once a compound or element has the tendency to attain noble gas structure, the compound will undergo chemical reaction.

As you move down a column or group, the ionic radius increases. This is because each row adds a new electron shell. Ionic radius decreases moving from left to right across a row or period.

Ionization energy is affected by the following factors

  1. Screening effect
  2. Orbital penetration
  3. Size of the nuclear charge
  4. Atomic radius

Ionization potential increases across the period, from left to right and decreases down the group.

Electronegativity also increases across the period, from left to right and decreases down the group.

Electron affinity also across the period, from left to right and decreases down the group.

But the atomic radius decreases across the period and increases down the group because of the increase in the number of shells down the group.

Electron affinity is the energy change that occurs when a gaseous atom acquires an electron to form a negative ion.

Ionization energy deals with the loss of electron while electron affinity deals with the gain of electron.

Example

A decrease in atomic size and an increase in nuclear charge across the period lead to

  1. A decrease in covalency in bond formation
  2. An increase in chemical reactivity
  3. An increase in the tendency to lose electron
  4. A decrease in electropositivity

NB: Across the period from left to right, the metallic character decreases. Hence the electropositivity of the element decreases. And this leads to increase in ionization energy, electronegativity, and electron affinity. D

Example

Element of the same period in the periodic table have the same 

  1. Chemical property, B. Physical property, C. Number of shell, D. Atomic number

NB: the principal quantum number determines the number of shells or orbit, and it also, determines the period an element belongs. Hence elements in the same period in the periodic table has the same number of shells.
